paragraphs.text: %md ## Identifying Customer Segments using K-Means Clustering Oracle Machine Learning supports clustering using several algorithms: k-Means, O-Cluster, and Expectation Maximization. In this notebook, we illustrate how to identify natural clusters of customers using the CUSTOMERS dataset from the SH schema using the unsupervised learning k-Means algorithm. The data exploration, preparation, and machine learning run inside Oracle Autonomous Database. See the documentation link below for details on the K-Means in-database algortihm. Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation ###### The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0 ---

msg.data:
Identifying Customer Segments using K-Means Clustering

Oracle Machine Learning supports clustering using several algorithms: k-Means, O-Cluster, and Expectation Maximization. In this notebook, we illustrate how to identify natural clusters of customers using the CUSTOMERS dataset from the SH schema using the unsupervised learning k-Means algorithm. The data exploration, preparation, and machine learning run inside Oracle Autonomous Database.

See the documentation link below for details on the K-Means in-database algortihm.

Copyright (c) 2021 Oracle Corporation

The Universal Permissive License (UPL), Version 1.0

paragraphs.text:
%md
![tiny arrow](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/database/options/advanced-analytics/clustering-5663171.jpg "tiny arrow")

paragraphs.text: %md Oracle ADW Documentation https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/index.html OML folder on Oracle Github : https://github.com/oracle/oracle-db-examples/tree/master/machine-learning OML web page: https://www.oracle.com/machine-learning OML ml-clustering: https://www.oracle.com/goto/ml-clustering OML K-Means: https://oracle.com/goto/ml-k-means

Oracle ADW Documentation https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/index.html
OML folder on Oracle Github : https://github.com/oracle/oracle-db-examples/tree/master/machine-learning
OML web page: https://www.oracle.com/machine-learning
OML ml-clustering: https://www.oracle.com/goto/ml-clustering
OML K-Means: https://oracle.com/goto/ml-k-means

paragraphs.title: Import libraries and set display options
paragraphs.text:
%python

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import oml

pd.set_option('display.max_rows', 500)
pd.set_option('display.max_columns', 500)
pd.set_option('display.width', 1000)

paragraphs.title: Prepare data by merging CUSTOMERS with SUPPLEMENTARY_DEMOGRAPHICS
paragraphs.text:
%python

CUSTOMERS = oml.sync(query = """SELECT CUST_ID, CUST_GENDER, CUST_MARITAL_STATUS, CUST_YEAR_OF_BIRTH, 
                                       CUST_INCOME_LEVEL, CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT 
                                FROM SH.CUSTOMERS""")
DEMO_DF = oml.sync(query = """SELECT CUST_ID, EDUCATION, AFFINITY_CARD, 
                                     HOUSEHOLD_SIZE, OCCUPATION, YRS_RESIDENCE, Y_BOX_GAMES
                              FROM SH.SUPPLEMENTARY_DEMOGRAPHICS""")
CUST_DF = CUSTOMERS.merge(DEMO_DF, how = "inner", on = 'CUST_ID',suffixes = ["",""])

paragraphs.title: Display the first 5 rows of CUST_DF data
paragraphs.text:
%python

z.show(CUST_DF.head())

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Build a k-Means model using the CUST_DF proxy object

msg.data: Build a k-Means model using the CUST_DF proxy object

paragraphs.title: Build k-Means clustering model with 3 clusters with default settings
Build k-Means clustering model with 3 clusters with explicit settings
paragraphs.text:
%python

try:
    oml.drop(model="CUST_CLUSTER_MODEL")
except:
    pass

setting = {'KMNS_ITERATIONS': 20, 
           'KMNS_CONV_TOLERANCE': .001,
           'KMNS_DISTANCE': 'KMNS_EUCLIDEAN',
           'KMNS_MIN_PCT_ATTR_SUPPORT': .1,
           'KMNS_NUM_BINS': 11,
           'KMNS_SPLIT_CRITERION': 'KMNS_VARIANCE',
           'KMNS_RANDOM_SEED': 7,
           'KMNS_DETAILS': 'KMNS_DETAILS_ALL',
           'ODMS_DETAILS': 'ODMS_ENABLE',
           'ODMS_SAMPLING': 'ODMS_SAMPLING_DISABLE',
           'PREP_AUTO': 'ON'}
km_mod = oml.km(n_clusters = 3, **setting).fit(CUST_DF, model_name = "CUST_CLUSTER_MODEL", case_id = 'CUST_ID')

paragraphs.title: Display k-Means model details
paragraphs.text:
%python

km_mod

paragraphs.title: Display model settings
paragraphs.text:
%python

km_mod.settings

paragraphs.title: Display cluster details for all clusters in the hierarchy with row counts and dispersion
paragraphs.text:
%python

z.show(km_mod.clusters)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Apply clustering model to assign rows to clusters
paragraphs.text:
%python

pred = km_mod.predict(CUST_DF, supplemental_cols = CUST_DF)

paragraphs.title: Use matplotlib scatterplot to view cluster results using birth year and years residence
paragraphs.text:
%python

pred_df = pred[['CUST_ID', 'CLUSTER_ID', 'CUST_YEAR_OF_BIRTH', 'YRS_RESIDENCE', 'CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT']].pull()

fig = plt.figure()
ax=fig.add_axes([0.1,0.1,0.8,0.8])

ids = pred_df['CLUSTER_ID']
clusters = ids.drop_duplicates().values
handles = []
labs = []
colors = ['r', 'b', 'g']
for i, c in enumerate(clusters):
    xc = pred_df[pred_df['CLUSTER_ID'] == c]['YRS_RESIDENCE'].values
    yc = pred_df[pred_df['CLUSTER_ID'] == c]['CUST_YEAR_OF_BIRTH'].values
    
    h = ax.scatter(xc, yc, color= colors[i])
    handles.append(h)
    labs.append('CLUSTER' + str(c))
ax.legend(handles, labs)
plt.title('K-Means Clustering')

plt.grid(True)

plt.xlabel('YRS_RESIDENCE')
plt.ylabel('CUST_YEAR_OF_BIRTH')
plt.show()

%md

### Compare clusters

Compare the feature distribution for year of birth in clusters 4 and 5. Cluster 4 tends to have middle aged individuals, while cluster 5 has more senior individuals.

msg.data:
Compare clusters

Compare the feature distribution for year of birth in clusters 4 and 5. Cluster 4 tends to have middle aged individuals, while cluster 5 has more senior individuals.

paragraphs.title: Distribution of the year of birth for cluster 4
paragraphs.text:
%python

feature = 'CUST_YEAR_OF_BIRTH' 

DF = pred[pred['CLUSTER_ID'] == 4].crosstab([feature])
z.show(DF.sort_values(feature))

paragraphs.text:
%md

### Using SQL access prediction details
One feature of OML is the ability to use models from SQL as well as Python. While OML4Py v1.0 does not expose prediction details through a Python API, such details are available through the SQL API, which is illustrated here.

We first create a table from the Python proxy object CUSTOMERS360 so that SQL can reference it. This could just as easily been a database view. 

Then, since prediction details are provided as an XML string, we extract the elements to present them as table columns. The 'first attribute' identfies the feature and value that most influences the cluster assignment with corresponding weight. This is followed by the second and third attribute. In this example, we provide three, but additional attributes could be presented as well.

msg.data:
Using SQL access prediction details

One feature of OML is the ability to use models from SQL as well as Python. While OML4Py v1.0 does not expose prediction details through a Python API, such details are available through the SQL API, which is illustrated here.

We first create a table from the Python proxy object CUSTOMERS360 so that SQL can reference it. This could just as easily been a database view.

Then, since prediction details are provided as an XML string, we extract the elements to present them as table columns. The 'first attribute' identfies the feature and value that most influences the cluster assignment with corresponding weight. This is followed by the second and third attribute. In this example, we provide three, but additional attributes could be presented as well.

paragraphs.title: Create table for use in SQL query
List 3 most relevant attributes for specific customers and likely cluster assignments
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT CUST_ID,
       CLUSTER_ID,
       ROUND(PROB*100,0) PROB_PCT,
       RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute1",17,100)),'rank="1"/>') FIRST_ATTRIBUTE,
       RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute2",17,100)),'rank="2"/>') SECOND_ATTRIBUTE,
       RTRIM(TRIM(SUBSTR(OUTPRED."Attribute3",17,100)),'rank="3"/>') THIRD_ATTRIBUTE
FROM (SELECT CUST_ID, S.CLUSTER_ID, PROBABILITY PROB, 
             CLUSTER_DETAILS(CUST_CLUSTER_MODEL USING T.*) DETAIL
      FROM (SELECT V.*, CLUSTER_SET(CUST_CLUSTER_MODEL, NULL, 0.2 USING *) PSET
            FROM CUSTOMERS360 V
            WHERE cust_id = ${CUST_ID ='101362','101362'|'102087'| '100456'}) T,
                  TABLE(T.PSET) S
            ORDER BY 2 DESC) OUT,
            XMLTABLE('/Details'
                      PASSING OUT.DETAIL
                      COLUMNS 
                      "Attribute1" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[1]',
                      "Attribute2" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[2]',
                      "Attribute3" XMLType PATH 'Attribute[3]') OUTPRED
